div1.head: Letter from C.C. Fletcher to Emilie Lawrence Reed, April 3, 1929
div1.opener:
UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE
BUREAU OF CHEMISTRY AND SOILS
WASHINGTON
April 3, 1929.
SOIL INVESTIGATIONS
CCF:P
Mrs. Walter Reed,
c/o The Burlington Hotel,
Vermont Avenue at Thomas Circle,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Madam:
div1.p:
Your letter requesting information on our opinion as to
the material removed from the soil by gladiolus when continuously
grown in the same soil, has been received.

In our opinion when you have treated the soil with the
bone-meal and manure which you applied you probably added sufficient
of the plant foods and any injury created will probably not be
because the soil was depleted. The difficulty in growing the same
crop on the soil year after year is not entirely a matter of plant
food, but is often a matter of injury from insects or disease which
will be increased when the same crop is grown on the land year after
year. If you are getting good results and are having no trouble I
see no reason why you should move the gladiolus to another location.

If we can be of any further service, do not hesitate to
command us.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, C. C. Fletcher
Associate Chemist
Soil Fertility Investigations.
